post_text:
(WSET) - At the September 17th Danville School Board meeting, the Board voted to move in the direction of bringing kids back into the building as long as certain health and safety criteria are met.

The Danville School Board gave the interim superintendent, Dr. Catherine Magouyrk, the ability to investigate what it would mean to bring those kids who chose face-to-face learning back into buildings. It also allows her to come up with a game plan for what would be required to do that. The main contributing factor to this is if COVID-19 cases continue to decline in the city.

We will keep you posted as soon as a plan has been APPROVED. As of now, this is investigational only and does not mean that the current virtual learning plan has changed.

The Danville School Board gave the interim superintendent, Dr. Catherine Magouyrk, the ability to investigate what it would mean to bring those kids who chose face-to-face learning back into buildings. It also allows her to come up with a game plan for what would be required to do that. The main contributing factor to this is if COVID-19 cases continue to decline in the city.

We will keep you posted as soon as a plan has been APPROVED. As of now, this is investigational only and does not mean that the current virtual learning plan has changed.

post_text: You may have heard from a recent article in the Register and Bee, the city was set to disconnect utilities to those households with delinquent accounts on August 31, 2020. At the request of Mayor Alonzo Jones, the City postponed those disconnections until Monday, September 14, 2020, so that customers had enough time to make financial arrangements. The attached document highlights several grant opportunities, administered by the city via Danville Social Services, that are available to qualified applicants in need of assistance with utilities, rent, mortgage, or housing.

post_text:
Superintendent Search Update!

The Virginia School Boards Association (VSBA) has been assisting the Danville City School Board in its search for a new Superintendent. The process began in July when the VSBA presented a timeline in which a new Superintendent will be named.

Since July, the school board has held a public meeting, asked for community feedback (survey) regarding the qualifications of the next Superintendent, and then shared those qualifications, as well as their own, with the VSBA in order to start the search process.

Applications were due to the VSBA in August. Below is a Profile Summary of the applicants. The next step is for the school board to conduct interviews with candidates - the interview dates will be announced at the regular school board meeting scheduled for Thursday, September 17, 2020.

We will provide additional updates as we move through the selection process.
text:
Superintendent Search Update!

The Virginia School Boards Association (VSBA) has been assisting the Danville City School Board in its search for a new Superintendent. The process began in July when the VSBA presented a timeline in which a new Superintendent will be named.

Since July, the school board has held a public meeting, asked for community feedback (survey) regarding the qualifications of the next Superintendent, and then shared those qualifications, as well as their own, with the VSBA in order to start the search process.

Applications were due to the VSBA in August. Below is a Profile Summary of the applicants. The next step is for the school board to conduct interviews with candidates - the interview dates will be announced at the regular school board meeting scheduled for Thursday, September 17, 2020.

We will provide additional updates as we move through the selection process.

Student and Family IT Help Desk Hours Changing!

After receiving feedback on our student and family help desk, we are modifying the schedule in an attempt to offer more flexibility for families. The new schedule (starting tomorrow, September 9) is listed below:

Monday, Wednesday, and Friday - 9:00 am until 12:00 pm
Tuesday & Thursday - 2:00 pm until 5:00 pm

This schedule is now in effect for Woodrow Wilson, Westwood, and GW in addition to the IT Support phone numbers listed below:

434.710.1408 | 434.710.1952 | 434.710.1417 | 434.710.1396

Thanks for your patience as we adapt to provide the best assistance possible to our families and students.

post_text:
What a great physically distanced and scheduled Preschool Open House! Parents and children were so excited to meet their teachers and see their classrooms. The teachers enjoyed the extended time to speak with just one family at a time to begin to build the crucial relationship between home and school.

All preschool safety protocols were shared with parents and the kids got to play a little before they left. Smiles were sensed under masked faces and the only tears heard were of preschoolers not wanting to leave.

At Grove Park “Beetoven” was there taking temperatures. We at Grove Park and Northside Preschools are excited about our wonderful year ahead.

post_text:
DPS is hearing from many parents/guardians who have questions and comments regarding lunch breaks and how it may/may not affect students being tardy for a class.

Please know that Danville Public Schools understands that there may be situations that arise during the daily feeding and lunch pick up times that may cause students to miss part of a class due to uncontrollable circumstances. Your child will not receive a whole day absence during this time, but will receive an Excused tardy if they log into class late. The Excused tardy will not cause any legal ramifications for truancy. Please communicate with your child's teacher regarding any barriers. We are committed to working together to give every student the opportunity to be successful.

shared_text:
River City TV was live.
August 25 at 11:11 AM ·

The Danville Public Library of Virginia is celebrating National Library Card Sign Up Month during September and is inviting everyone to sign up for their FREE card if they live within a 50 mile radius of the Ruby B. Archie Library Building in Patton Street.

Also during the month of September you can have any fines incurred up to $50 waved when you donated school supplies to their “Fines for Supplies” campaign.

The Library also offers FREE WiFi and internet access for those who are tackling the virtual learning world.

shared_text:
River City TV was live.
August 17 at 1:48 PM ·

Danville Parks and Recreation is offering Virtual Learning Centers at both Coates and Glenwood Recreation Centers beginning Aug 24th for ages 5-12.

The program will run Monday-Friday from 7:30am until 6pm and follow all CDC guidelines for social distancing. Students will be separated into small groups and provided learning support through internet access and learning assistance from staff.

Danville Public Schools will provide breakfast, lunch and a take home dinner.

Space is limited so contact 434-799-5150 to register your child today!

post_text:
INFO FOR STUDENT AND PARENT ORIENTATION
● Monday, August 17 thru Friday, August 21
● Schools will send Invitations and detailed information to parents regarding times and procedures
● One parent may accompany the student
● CDC guidelines for social distancing and wearing masks will be required
● Temperatures will be taken upon entry
● Students and parents will be guided to specific stations by staff to receive information; complete forms; and pick up resources and devices
● Students and parents will be meeting in small groups in designated areas
● Teachers and administrators will review virtual learning expectations, schedules, resource and protocols and procedures
● Teachers will assist students and parents with logging on student devices and navigating websites

post_text: Melba, thank you for your 65 years of service!!! #DPSSTRONG
shared_text:
Danville Police Department
August 14 at 2:49 PM ·

The Danville Police Department was honored to celebrate the life of Melba Tanksley with her family today.

Melba Tanksley served the city of Danville as a school crossing guard for 65 years. She helped three generations of students arrive at school safely. She served a shining example of dedication and professionalism in the community.

Tanksley believed it was her duty to be at her assignment for as long as she was physically able in order to protect those children because she felt like they were her own. She will be remembered for her kindness and her family said that she never knew a stranger.

Melba Gosney Tanksley passed away August 11. She was 98 years young.

Hotspot Deployment Dates & Times!

DPS families without access to the internet at their residence may pick up a WiFi hotspot at the following locations during orientation week. Please note that times may differ from that school’s orientation. Only parents or guardians may pick up hotspots and a photo ID must be provided.

Woodrow Wilson - N. Main Street entrance
GWHS - CTE Parking Lot (se habla español)
Westwood - Park in bus loop and look for signs
Gibson - Gym entrance

Monday, August 17 - 10am-2pm
Tuesday, August 18 - 10am-2pm & 5-7pm
Wednesday, August 19 -10am-2pm & 5-7pm
Thursday, August 20 - 10am-2pm

post_text:
The Dept. of Child Nutrition was honored at last night’s school board meeting. A resolution from the General Assembly, and signed by Delegate Danny Marshall, was presented to the department in recognition of its inclusion in the No Kid Hungry Summer Hall of Fame for 2019!

In regard to meal distribution for this year, Child Nutrition has served close to 400,000 meals since schools closed in March due to COVID-19.

Pictured are Crystal Cobbs, School Board Chair, and Phillip Gardner, Director of Child Nutrition.

post_text:
Registration for School Reopening Form!

All school-aged children in Virginia must attend school, and we are excited that you have chosen to allow your child to attend Danville Public Schools. In order to plan for instruction, transportation, and nutrition, we need you to register your child for program participation. If your child did not attend Danville Public Schools last year, you will have to register him/her at the appropriate zoned school, as well. At a later date, parents will be required to complete additional information required by their child's school.

(PLEASE COMPLETE THIS FORM FOR EACH SCHOOL-AGED CHILD IN YOUR HOUSEHOLD.) In order to ensure bus transportation is provided, this form must be completed by Friday, August 7, 2020. Links to the form have been provided in both English and Spanish.

Spanish https://bit.ly/3fG0C92

Congratulations to Jax and his family!

post_text:
Teachers,

You will be returning shortly to a school year start you have never faced before. We want to support you and your students by providing you the resources that will help you teach in a virtual or blended learning environment. We want to hear your voice regarding your professional learning needs. Please complete the survey below as soon as possible so we can develop the training you will need in utilizing a learning management system (LMS). Once the survey is completed, there will be a Google Meet opportunity at each school to discuss with consultants your areas of need and any concerns you may have working in the virtual and blended learning environment. We want your ideas, thoughts and voice. So let's get started!

Dr. Catherine Magouyrk

https://bit.ly/teacherlearningsurvey2020

post_text:
PUBLIC HEARING
SCHOOL BOARD OF THE
CITY OF DANVILLE
Superintendent Search
Tuesday, July 28, 2020
6:30 P.M.

A Public hearing will be held by the School Board of the City of Danville, Virginia, in the Danville Room of the School Board Office, 341 Main Street, Danville, Virginia, on the 28th day of July, 2020, at 6:30 p.m. At that time, the School Board will receive written and oral comments from citizens concerning qualifications for the next Superintendent. Should circumstances prevent attendance at the meeting, please contact Anne Moore-Sparks at 434-799-6400 for more information.

post_text:
The Danville School Board met tonight to discuss the PROPOSED Reopening Plan and the PROPOSED calendar revisions for the 2020-2021 school year.

DPS encourages the public to view these documents:
PROPOSED Reopening Plan - https://bit.ly/3eD4Mhk
PROPOSED Calendar Revisions - https://bit.ly/3fBroQp

DPS also encourages community input in regard to the proposed plans via Let's Talk! With Let’s Talk!, anyone can submit a question, comment, concern, suggestion, or compliment 24 hours a day, seven days a week from any computer, tablet, or smartphone. Submissions may be anonymous, but the division guarantees a direct response for people who leave their contact information.

To start a conversation, simply click the Let’s Talk! Contact Us tab, located in the lower right-hand corner of the DPS website at https://www.danvillepublicschools.org/, and select a topic. There’s also an app for iOS and Android devices. After downloading the Let’s Talk! app, users can enter the DPS ID number (DC2636) to access the Danville Public Schools’ Let’s Talk! page.

We want to hear from you! #DSPSTRONG

post_text:
Today, the National School Public Relations Association awarded Patrick Stowe, the Technical Support Specialist with Danville Public Schools, with two Publications and Digital Media Awards! Patrick won the Award of Merit for both his Teacher Appreciation video and the DPS Recruitment video!

The Publications and Digital Media Awards recognize outstanding publications, e-newsletters, digital media programs, marketing materials, videos, social media, websites, and more.

There were more than 700 entries submitted this year. Patrick's talents are no surprise to those at DPS and it is wonderful to see him recognized at a national level. #DPSSTRONG

https://www.facebook.com/2367783859916148/videos/843698159303073
shared_text:
Danville Public Schools
May 6, 2019 at 11:24 AM ·

We are truly honored to work with the best and brightest educators in the nation. Because of you, young lives in our city are being transformed every day! Thank you for everything you do!

post_text:
Danville Public Schools is excited to announce our Teaching with Tech 2020 - Virtual Technology Conference on Monday, July 20, 2020, and Friday, July 24, 2020. This online technology conference is FREE and open to ALL educators!

Please browse through over 60+ sessions that are available during the two-day conference! We have trainers and vendors from Virginia to California to help integrate technology into your classroom, whether it is virtual or face to face! *Please note that some sessions do require you to sign up/register for the session!

Recertification points will be awarded to those attendees that participate in 5 or more hours of training!

Click on the links in the below flyer to view the sessions, descriptions, times, and presenters for each day!

https://docs.google.com/drawings/d/1FxlykTJ1EUpHV8qEEdXTqwp_As2W0cBraGyy5US1w9o/edit?usp=sharing

post_text:
DPS Reopening Update!

DPS is working diligently on its reopening plan, collecting stakeholder input from recent surveys and meeting several times a week with various reopening task force groups to discuss the logistics of reopening safely for our students and staff. While we are limited in what we can share at this time because we need final State approval, we can share that we are PROPOSING a plan that will focus on both remote and face-to-face learning. Thank you for your patience during this unprecedented time and stay tuned to additional information soon! #DPSStrong
text:
DPS Reopening Update!

DPS is working diligently on its reopening plan, collecting stakeholder input from recent surveys and meeting several times a week with various reopening task force groups to discuss the logistics of reopening safely for our students and staff. While we are limited in what we can share at this time because we need final State approval, we can share that we are PROPOSING a plan that will focus on both remote and face-to-face learning. Thank you for your patience during this unprecedented time and stay tuned to additional information soon! #DPSStrong

post_text: DPS served 123,312 meals in the month of June. Meals were distributed to children via 23 meal distribution sites throughout the city! Since April, DPS has served 244,268 meals. Shoutout to our Child Nutrition staff and bus drivers for making this happen! #DPSStrong

On June 16, 2020, DPS posted the Modified Dress Code for Middle School students who will be attending Bonner and Westwood Middle Schools for the 2020-2021 school year. After receiving questions in regard to the color of shirts and shirts with slogans, graphics, or messages, DPS has revised the document to clear up any confusion - please see below. post_text:
Proposed Revision of the Adopted 2020-2021 Calendar!

The challenges presented by the Covid-19 epidemic necessitate an adjustment to the adopted 2020-2021 calendar. Additional time is needed prior to opening school for students to prepare school staff to meet these challenges. The proposed changes will be presented to the School Board on July 9, 2020. Feedback from school stakeholders will be collected from July 2, 2020, until July 8, 2020.

To view proposed changes: https://bit.ly/ProposedRevision

Please share your feedback on the proposed changes, outlined in this communication, at calendarfeedback@mail.dps.k12.va.us

post_text:
DANVILLE PUBLIC SCHOOL BOARD ANNOUNCES SUPERINTENDENT DESIGNEE!

The Danville Public School Board met on Thursday, June 25, 2020. At this meeting, the Board approved Ms. Robin Owens as the Superintendent’s designee, effective July 1, 2020. Ms. Owens has served Danville Public Schools since 1988 as a teacher, Assistant Principal, and Principal. Currently, Ms. Owens serves as the Director of Student Intervention Services. She has served in this role since 2015.

Ms. Owens will serve as the Superintendent Designee until an Interim Superintendent is appointed by the newly elected Danville Public School Board on July 9, 2020.
text:
DANVILLE PUBLIC SCHOOL BOARD ANNOUNCES SUPERINTENDENT DESIGNEE!

The Danville Public School Board met on Thursday, June 25, 2020. At this meeting, the Board approved Ms. Robin Owens as the Superintendent’s designee, effective July 1, 2020. Ms. Owens has served Danville Public Schools since 1988 as a teacher, Assistant Principal, and Principal. Currently, Ms. Owens serves as the Director of Student Intervention Services. She has served in this role since 2015.

Ms. Owens will serve as the Superintendent Designee until an Interim Superintendent is appointed by the newly elected Danville Public School Board on July 9, 2020.

The DPS School Board Meeting was extremely emotional this evening. Best wishes to our Superintendent, Stan Jones as he moves on in his career path. I am thankful for the one year I was able to work for DPS during your leadership. Thank you for believing in me and supporting my passion for literacy. Hopefully, you will not have to deal with more Molly Lous in your future. 😊 I hope to continue to make you proud and continue to serve DPS well.

post_text:
DPS had four Gear Up Virginia students chosen as Student Ambassadors! We are super proud that these students were selected on behalf of our district. They competed with other GEAR Up students from across Virginia for one spot on each of Virginia’s Universities, Colleges, and Community Colleges. Congratulations to the following:

Galileo Magnet High School - La'Daviona Carter for Danville Community College and Luke Garcia for the University of Virginia.

George Washington High School- India Womack for Virginia Tech and NaKiyah Echols for Hampton University.

Each of these students will receive an extra $1,000 scholarship in addition to their $5,000 GUV scholarship. Plus they will receive either a Chromebook or iPad. #DPSStrong

post_text:
O.T. Bonner Middle School Invites You to be Recognized for Moving on to High School!

June 8, 2020

Students with Last Names A-H, Please come at 10AM.

Students with Last Names I-Z, Please come at 11:30AM.

Each student is allowed ONE car. Please enter Apollo Avenue from Audubon Drive (near Westwood Middle) and proceed into the Westwood Bus Loop (located between Westwood and Bonner). From the Westwood Bus Loop, cars will be directed into the Bonner Car Loop for the Drive Thru Recognition.

(NOTE: There will be NO left turns into the Westwood Bus Loop.)

After entering the Bonner Car Loop, each car will stop at the steps in front of Bonner Middle, only the student will exit the car, receive a certificate, and have his/her photo taken. Cars will exit the Bonner Car Loop by turning right and proceeding to Piney Forest Road. Photos from the Drive Thru Recognition will be posted on the Bonner website.

Congratulations!

We Look Forward to Seeing you June 8!

Because of COVID-19 restrictions the graduates each had an allotted time to travel through the halls of Galileo one last time and stop at numerous stations where their high school days were remember. Teachers lined the halls with positive messages, official photos were taken, video messages recorded, a special slide show was shown and it all culminated with a walk across the stage to receive their diploma. Family members remained in their cars as the students traveled the halls and had a dedicated space outside their cars to watch their child accept their diploma.

Congratulations graduates on your special day and also to the facility and staff of the Danville Public Schools who made this day extra special during these extraordinary times.

post_text:
For Parents, Guardians, and 8th grade students at Westwood Middle School:

You and your 8th grade student are invited to Westwood Middle School's Drive Thru 8th grade Promotion Ceremony. The ceremony will take place next Thursday, June 4 from 10 am to 12 noon at Westwood. We are asking that parents and students simply drive up and remain in their cars. Your child will hear his or her name called and be handed a packet as they drive up. Again, no one is to get out of their cars as we want to keep the traffic flowing and abide by Covid-19 guidelines. If you are unable to attend, student packets will be mailed home at a later date. Again, the date and time is next Thursday, June 4 from 10 am to 12 noon.
We hope to see you there, have a great evening!

post_text: More "Feeding the Mind & Body" photos. Thank you, Danville Riverview Rotary! #PartnershipsMatter
text: More "Feeding the Mind & Body" photos. Thank you, Danville Riverview Rotary! #PartnershipsMatter

post_text: #PartnershipsMatter
shared_text:
Danville Riverview Rotary
May 22 at 6:39 PM ·

Danville Riverview Rotary, Danville Public Schools, DPS Education Foundation, Danville Public Library, Friends of the Library, Smart Beginnings, Danville Pittsylvania County, and local volunteers teamed up recently to provide local students with reading material in cooperation with the schools meals distribution program.

Over 50 volunteers from Rotary, the school system, the library, and the community handed out around 2600 books at the 13 locations serviced by Danville Public schools' meal distribution program. While the majority of books were purchased by Rotary with funds from a Rotary District grant, the Doris Wilson Literacy Fund with the DPS Education Foundation, and the Friends of the Danville Public Library, a large portion was donated by the Danville Public Library. #RotaryStory
text:
#PartnershipsMatter

post_text: The Danville Public Schools Education Foundation is proud to announce these scholarships!!!!
shared_text:
Galileo Magnet High School Counseling Department is with Danville Public Schools and Galileo Magnet High School at Galileo Magnet High School.
May 22 at 10:35 AM · Danville, VA ·

Terri Hall, Chair of the Danville School Board, presents this year’s Bryan Wells Scholarship and Booker Award(s) to three outstanding Galileo students. Thank you to Danville Public Schools for providing our students with this opportunity!

The Bryan Wells Memorial Scholarship ($2,000) is given to a Galileo student in memory of Bryan Wells, beloved son, brother, and friend.

The Booker Award ($2,000) is given annually to two former Glenwood Elementary School students in memory of Jack and Ilah Tate Booker and in honor of their daughter, Margaret Booker Gabel.

Chuck Vipperman‎G.W. Eagles Football
May 21 at 3:04 PM ·

This is the stuff I LOVE to share.

The Danville Public Schools' (DPS) Honor Program recognizes students with a Grade Point Average of 3.2 or above. Ninety-two (92) students from both Galileo Magnet High School and George Washington High School achieved this honor for the 2019-2020 academic year.

And that includes SEVEN members of the GW Football team!

Gemonye’ Glass

Jayden Worsham

Wesley Graves

Tyler McDuffie

Tylee Myers

Shawn Watlington Jr.

Jalen Williamson

I can't remember the last time we had SEVEN honor grads in one year! We only had 18 seniors listed on the roster!

Congrats to these guys! That's a lot of star power AND brain power in a single class!

(Pictured: Honor graduates Wesley Graves and Tyler McDuffie

post_text:
Robin Owens, the Director for Student Support Services for DPS, was interviewed for this article in the Washington Post. The article discusses how the closure of schools can impact child abuse cases.

“In Danville Public Schools, educators are taking advantage of the few glimpses of children they still get. The school system is delivering meals by bus to its nearly 6,000 students in rural Southern Virginia, where 1 in 4 families live below the poverty line. On those trips, said director for student support services Robin Owens, nutrition staffers make sure to “engage with families” as much as they can and try to catch sight of children.

The school system also sent child abuse prevention resources to principals and school counselors, Owens said, including a 12-step pamphlet Danville staff were asked to distribute to parents. The pamphlet lists a dozen alternatives to lashing out at children acting inappropriately: Splash cold water on your face. Hug a pillow.

“Close your eyes,” one reads, “and imagine you’re hearing what your child is about to hear.””
shared_text:

With kids stuck at home, ER doctors see more severe cases of child abuse

post_text:
Corey Williams, a 10th grade English teacher at GW, talks openly about his frustration in not getting to see his students and his excitement in learning to teach differently due to COVID-19. Thank you to all DPS teachers who are rising to the occasion by thinking creatively and "outside of the box" in order to ensure continuity of instruction! #DPSStrong

Williams, 26, said he learned so much about classroom management and building relationships with his students during his first year as a teacher. He called all of the adjustments “frustrating” and found the new methods of teaching to be somewhat impersonal.

“You don’t know what kids are going through on the other side of the screen,” he said. “They could be hungry and not know where their next meal is coming from, but I’m having to give all these assignments and set all these expectations.”

Despite that, Williams is hopeful that these circumstances will give him an opportunity to make future lessons more flexible.

“I’ve already got ideas in mind for how things will work in case of an emergency,” he said.

post_text:
DPS Recognizes Three Companies For Their Support!

At the school board meeting held on April 9, 2020, the Danville School Board recognized Essel Propack Official, Floor Care Specialists (FCS), and American National Bank & Trust (AMNB) for their strong support of the division’s schools. The businesses were honored as part of the Virginia School Boards Association’s 2020 Business Honor Roll program. The program, in its fourth year, gives school divisions a way to say “thank you” to local businesses and recognize them for their valuable contributions to the schools.

“The school division and its students, board members, administrators, and staff would like to express sincere appreciation for all that these businesses do for the children of our community,” according to Terri Hall, School Board Chair. “These three partners have donated their time, talent, and financial resources to support DPS programs and initiatives designed to prepare our 5,500 students for a 21st century economy.”

For the full release, visit https://www.danvillepublicschools.org/

#PartnershipsMatter

My GWHS Jobs for Virginia Graduates (JVG) students really appreciated it. So did I.

post_text:
DPS Announces Tentative Graduation Dates!

Graduation is an important milestone in the lives of our students at George Washington High School and Galileo Magnet High School. Pending the ever-evolving impact of the Coronavirus Pandemic and the Governor’s Executive Order 53 closing school for the remainder of the year, the tentative plans for graduation ceremonies, as of today, are as follows:

· Galileo Magnet High School Commencement Ceremony - Friday, July 10, 2020, 7:00 pm - George Washington High School Auditorium

· George Washington High School Commencement Ceremony - Saturday, July 11, 2020, 7:00 pm - Averett University North Campus

While it is our desire to celebrate our graduating seniors, our challenge is not knowing what the future holds in regard to lifting the “social distancing” requirement and the ban on 10 or more people in public places issued by Governor Northam. Please be reminded that the dates for graduation are tentative should the Executive Order be lifted. Please stay tuned for additional information and further guidance.

· George Washington High School Commencement Ceremony - Saturday, July 11, 2020, 7:00 pm - Averett University North Campus

While it is our desire to celebrate our graduating seniors, our challenge is not knowing what the future holds in regard to lifting the “social distancing” requirement and the ban on 10 or more people in public places issued by Governor Northam. Please be reminded that the dates for graduation are tentative should the Executive Order be lifted. Please stay tuned for additional information and further guidance.

The Danville School Board will meet Thursday, April 16, as scheduled but follow social distancing guidelines amid the COVID-19 outbreak. The meeting will be held in the Danville Room at the School Board Office beginning at 6 p.m.

post_text: So, DPS and Sovah Health - Danville did a thing today! As it turns out, Cheryl Brumfield, Dr. Gary Miller, and Renee Hughes (SOVAH Pharmacist and DPS School Board Member) conspired and came up with a great idea. Since schools are closed for the remainder of the year, they reached out to DPS to see if we could donate any unused PPE items such as masks, gloves, and gowns. Today, we delivered on our promise. Pictured: Cheryl Brumfield (Senior Executive Assistant, SOVAH), Dr. Gary Miller (SOVAH Cardiologist and City Council Member), Sherry Wright (DPS School Health Facilitator), and John Kent (COO, SOVAH). #DPSStrong #SOVAHStrong #PartnershipsMatter

post_text:
Superintendent's Update 4.3.20

Information regarding continuity of instruction will be forthcoming from your child’s school level administrative team next week. It includes information about report cards for the third quarter which will be mailed next week. Because of the volume and details of the message coming from your school’s principal, it is very important that you listen to the message in its entirety when you receive it next week.

It is important that you check your emails regularly for information coming directly from your child’s school. You may also find updated information on the DPS website as well as our social media sites.

Thank you for your patience, support, and understanding during this challenging time. Please stay healthy and safe!

To meet the guidelines, the Danville Room will be modified, and some board members may participate remotely. No member of the public will be allowed to be physically present during the meeting. The public may view the school board meeting live on Youtube at https://www.youtube.com/user/dpslive

post_text: Because of rapidly changing developments regarding the spread of Covid-19 and Governor Northam’s Stay at Home order, DPS cannot distribute Chromebooks to families of third through fifth graders at this time. After consultation with several experts, we believe this in the best interest of our families, staff, and public safety. We sincerely apologize for any confusion we have caused as our plans are rapidly changing during a very fluid situation. Please continue to monitor the DPS website and stay in contact with your teachers for the most current information. #DPSStrong

post_text:
Fredrick Douglas wrote, “Once you learn to read you will forever be free.” It is our focus at DPS to provide all students with a solid literacy foundation. Literacy is our students’ life chance for a successful future. We want to ensure all students are provided with the skills for a successful future.
Several months ago we began our journey with Ms. Mills with a video about her dedication to small group instruction. Her prediction in late 2019 was that her students would show vast improvement in their January testing scores. This video is proof that our dedicated teachers are making a difference!

Paloma won 3rd place in the Virginia School Board Association's Regional Art Contest with her work titled, "Itsa Me"! Paloma created this in the class Art Foundations 1, which is a class in which 8th graders earn high school credit. Sara Emerson, her teacher, said that Paloma is supremely talented and everything she creates is beyond wonderful! We are all so proud of her!

post_text:
Zachary Parker, Sydney Litton, and Kimberly Waller-Petty of Galileo Magnet High School won first place for Website Design in the FBLA Longwood Regional Competition.

Since the event was cancelled at Longwood, these students had to film themselves and send it into the judges. They have been working since October of 2019 to build a website based on an airline service. They made the website so the user could look up different destinations from different airports based on specific dates. The user could also “book” these flights.

Megan Nipper, the CTE teacher at Galileo, said, "I am so proud of all their efforts and that they took the initiative to submit a video displaying their website to the judges since they could no longer showcase it in person."
text:
Zachary Parker, Sydney Litton, and Kimberly Waller-Petty of Galileo Magnet High School won first place for Website Design in the FBLA Longwood Regional Competition.

Since the event was cancelled at Longwood, these students had to film themselves and send it into the judges. They have been working since October of 2019 to build a website based on an airline service. They made the website so the user could look up different destinations from different airports based on specific dates. The user could also “book” these flights.

Megan Nipper, the CTE teacher at Galileo, said, "I am so proud of all their efforts and that they took the initiative to submit a video displaying their website to the judges since they could no longer showcase it in person."

post_text:
Ms. Jennifer Underwood, a preschool teacher at Grove Park, bought these note cards and printed these pictures with the excitement of telling her students that they would see each other soon. Yesterday brought a totally different meaning to sitting down and writing these after the Governor announced that school was closed for the remainder of the academic year.

"I can’t believe these children will never walk through my classroom door again as my students," stated Ms. Underwood. "So many tears have already been shed and I know many more will come. I didn’t get the chance to say good-bye and it’s truly heartbreaking. I hope this mail and pictures bring smiles to these children and they realize how special they are!" #DPSStrong #EverychildEverydayEveryclassroom

post_text:
Danville Public Schools is committed to providing engaging learning experiences for students during extended school closure. Teaching teams at our schools are developing DPS Learning Plans for priority content areas to ensure students remain engaged with course content during extended school closure.

These plans provide a variety of “at home” learning experiences for students to apply prior knowledge of course content. Students may provide evidence of completing the activities in the Learning Plans upon returning to school. We encourage students to work on these activities at a pace that works best for your family. No additional work will be assigned and no grades will be posted during the closure period.

Paper copies of DPS Learning Plans will be available for pick-up at all schools on Wednesday, March 18, 2020, from 1:00 p.m. to 5:30 p.m.

Electronic copies of the learning plans and materials can be accessed at http://bit.ly/2vw5YCx which is also located on the DPS website and on each school website.

Families may use email to maintain contact with teachers.

post_text:
Coronavirus Update 3.17.20

Please be reminded that learning materials are available for pick up tomorrow, Wednesday, March 18th, from 1:00 pm - 5:30 pm at your child’s school. Principals will communicate directly with families this evening via School Messenger.

You will be able to access electronic copies of the learning plans and materials after 1:00 pm tomorrow, Wednesday, March 18th, on the DPS website and on each school website.

In addition to the distribution of learning materials, DPS will provide one (1) Chromebook per family for middle school and high school students who currently have no device. Existing fees due to loss or damage will be waived for all students. Families may pick up devices at Westwood, Bonner, Galileo, and GW tomorrow, Wednesday, March 18th, from 1:00 pm - 5:30 pm. For those students in need of internet access, you may access free wifi at these locations: https://bit.ly/2xJGAdf

post_text:
Trevon Mease is our latest GED Graduate. Trevon was an excellent student and we will miss him. You might remember seeing his brother, Tommie, featured as one of our graduates last month. Both brothers are interested in serving in our military. Good luck to you both.

We look forward to having our students back in our classroom, but in the meantime, we are busy preparing to serve you online. Our current students will be contacted with several options to continue working on their educational goals while the schools are closed.

If you have any questions, you may contact Mary Dumont at mdumont@mail.dps.k12.va.us.

DPS Update - 3.16.20

Please be advised that information is changing rapidly; therefore, we will communicate with you on an ongoing basis.

For now, Tuesday, March 17th and Wednesday, March 18th are teacher and nurse workdays. Teachers and nurses will report to school OR work remotely to prepare learning opportunities for the continuity of education. Work hours will be 8:00 am - 3:00 pm.

On March 18th, families can pick up learning materials at their child’s school. Pick up times will be from 1:00 pm - 5:30 pm. Principals will communicate pickup procedures directly with families.

DPS is closed from Thursday, March 19th to Friday, March 27th. NO staff member is required to report to work.

As always, thank you for your patience and understanding during this unprecedented time.

Tonya Fullerwinder
March 13 at 9:47 PM ·

GW students in Ms. Fullerwinder's Personal Finance and Jobs for Virginia Graduates (JVG) classes were honored to have speakers from URW Credit Union spend time with them. Jo Setliff and Ronnie Glass educated the youth about budgeting, credit scores, and check writing. They engaged the students by using several interactive activities. Their visit has become an annual event, thus highlighting the importance of community partnerships in the education process. Pictured with Mrs. Setliff and Mr. Glass are students Ms. Fullerwinder's second block, JVG class.

shared_text:
Tonya Fullerwinder is with Henry Motley and Melissa Tuck.
March 11 at 10:37 PM ·

GWHS JVG students, under the direction of Ms. Tonya Fullerwinder, were honored to hear from two members of the community: Melissa Tuck, who is a mitigation specialist and Retired Command Sergeant Major Henry Motley.

The speakers shared pertinent life and career information with the students. Ms. Tuck provided insight about legal services available for persons who cannot otherwise afford assistance. She also talked about how connections and simple conversations can lead to opportunities. CSM Motley educated the students who desire to go into the military about what they can expect and all that the military offers those who enlist.
#community
#jvg
#partnershipsmatter
#DPS
#ittakesavillage

post_text:
Schoolfield Elementary Celebrates Read Across America Week!

Schoolfield Elementary started "Read Across America Week with Kindness" last Monday. Students that were seen providing acts of kindness were awarded a “Horton Be Kind” coin! We also celebrated all week with, “Teacher in a Hat”. Teachers wore their striped cat in the hats during guided reading. Wednesday, students studied Dr. Seuss’ Wonderifulous Words and tried to figure out meanings using context clues. Thursday, we learned about our favorite teachers’ favorite book! And finally on Friday our Book Fair opened and will run through March 13th.

As a special treat, volunteer readers from American National Bank and Trust came all week to share the love of books and stories with our students!

Thank you to our volunteer readers: Voinda Garrett, Doris Kendrick, Karen Lewis, Stetson Franklin, Marilyn Schow Merricks, Randy McDaniel, Katie Smith, Jackie Bliss, Jeff Haley, Cheryl Searles, and Karen Beale. #PartnershipsMatter

post_text:
Galileo High School is proud to present the Tony Award-winning musical "Into the Woods" by Stephen Sondheim and James Lapine this coming month. Jack, Little Red Riding Hood, Cinderella and the cast of Rapunzel come together when all of their stories intersect and are forced to face their fears...in the woods!

The play will be performed at the O.T. Bonner Middle School Auditorium at 7pm on April 2-3. Tickets are $10 ($5 for DPS staff) and can be purchased at the door.

We have been celebrating Dr. Seuss at Northside Preschool!

The faculty and children have been reading, reading reading! Northside is really showing children the fun in reading books. Practicing comparing math quantities with the book "Ten Apples Up on Top" in Ms. Petty's class and "Wacky Wednesday" in Mrs. Smith's class. Look at the cute socks worn on the day the "Fox in Sox" was read in Mrs. Walker's class. We even had Sheriff Mondul to come to read. What a treat!

Practicing comparing math quantities with the book "Ten Apples Up on Top" in Ms. Petty's class and "Wacky Wednesday" in Mrs. Smith's class. Look at the cute socks worn on the day the "Fox in Sox" was read in Mrs. Walker's class. We even had Sheriff Mondul to come to read. What a treat!

post_text:
Chrystal Smith, Andrea Mann, and Charlotte Melton attended the Youth Mental Health First Aid USA training course offered at Danville-Pittsylvania Community Services yesterday. Pictured with them after receiving their certificates is Dominick Grembi, Prevention Program Services Manager for DPCS.

It was a very informative, and educational, eight- hour training course, that touched on mental health issues most commonly affecting the youth of today, and how to identify and intervene in a mental health crises.

post_text:
The Badcock Home Furniture &more "Teacher of the Month" initiative awarded Dr. Sheila Robinson of Schoolfield Elementary with a $50 gift card today.

A $50 gift card will also be awarded to a middle school teacher in March and a high school teacher in April. Principals were asked to nominate a teacher that goes "above and beyond" for students. Those names were then entered into a drawing.

"Dr. Robinson is always willing to offer any assistance in the areas of classroom management, the academic success of students, and the mentoring of peers and coworkers," said Mr. Everett Johnson, Schoolfield Principal. "She is an advocate of student achievement and is always looking for ways to take students to another level."

Pictured below: Charnese Bennett (Badcock manager) and Dr. Robinson.

Thank you, Badcock Furniture, for recognizing the wonderful job that our teachers do on a daily basis!

#PartnershipsMatter

post_text:
REMINDER!!!! Tomorrow, March 3rd is now a teacher workday!

Upon the recommendation of the Director of School Safety, Mr. William Chaney and our law enforcement partners and in an effort to ensure the safety of our students and community, Tuesday, March 3, 2020, is now scheduled to be a teacher workday.

No students are to report to school Tuesday, March 3, 2020.

Teacher workdays allow teachers and support staff the opportunity to catch up on work, attend meetings, continue to prepare for upcoming SOL's, and focus on any other work directly related and centered around curriculum. This will also allow easy access, with no disruption to students, to the citizens of Danville who will participate in Super Tuesday, the Democratic Party presidential primary, scheduled to be held at 8 of our schools that have been identified as voting precincts.

post_text: Over the last couple of weeks, Ms.Pyles's 5th grade class at Schoolfield has been studying the ocean floor. They have studied everything from what the ocean looks like, the life found in the ocean, the effects people have on the ocean, to why it is salty. As part of this study, the students made models of the ocean floor using the information found in their notebooks and non-fiction resources. As you can see, Ms. Pyles's kids are very creative in identifying and labeling ocean floor key parts that include: continental shelf, continental slope, continental rise, abyssal plain, ocean trenches, seamount, guyots, and mid-oceanic ridges.

They have studied everything from what the ocean looks like, the life found in the ocean, the effects people have on the ocean, to why it is salty. As part of this study, the students made models of the ocean floor using the information found in their notebooks and non-fiction resources. As you can see, Ms. Pyles's kids are very creative in identifying and labeling ocean floor key parts that include: continental shelf, continental slope, continental rise, abyssal plain, ocean trenches, seamount, guyots, and mid-oceanic ridges.

post_text: Today, the Danville Police Department awarded William "Billy" Chaney with the Danville Police Department Partnership Award. Mr. Chaney, the Director of Safety and Security for Danville Public Schools, has worked tirelessly to implement training for the city’s first responders for a response to a mass casualty incident that happened in 2019 at Galileo High School. He set up monthly meetings with multiple partners to implement the response and put together a tabletop exercise and a live training scenario for the police department to practice their response. Congrats, Billy!!! #PartnershipsMatter

Headphones Purchased Using Grant Funds from City of Danville!

Students in Miss Fallen's fourth grade class at Gibson Elementary are enjoying the new institutional headphones purchased through the City of Danville School Supply Grant Fund of the DPS Education Foundation. In January, Miss Fallen was awarded $250 to purchase a class set of headphones and a storage container. The headphones will allow all students to obtain equal access to listening devices. By having a class set of sanitizable headphones, all students will be able to use the devices for their auditory learning activities. #PartnershipsMatter

post_text:
Our area is expected to get snowfall tomorrow afternoon and into the night. It is undetermined when the rain will turn into snow, and how much accumulation we will get in our city. Because we are uncertain of what to expect, and we do not want to put our students and staff at risk, Danville Public Schools will operate on an early dismissal schedule tomorrow, Thursday, February 20th, 2020. Also, after school activities are cancelled for tomorrow as well. You can find the early dismissal schedule: https://www.danvillepublicschools.org/cms/one.aspx?portalId=158906&pageId=5678390

Thank you and be safe.

post_text:
Schoolfield Elementary held its annual Heart Challenge on Friday, February 14th, 2020. In the over 35 year history of Jump Rope For Heart, the American Heart Association has been able to impact many lives thanks to the support of students and teachers. Over the years, they have funded scientists who went on to win Nobel Prizes for their work! The American Heart Association has been able to work with health care providers to reduce the number of people dying from heart disease and those achievements are all because of the lifesaving donations from our community and school and others like us!

Schoolfield raised over $3500.00 dollars. Students danced, jumped, twisted and shouted their way through some fun activities in the school gym. Parents provided snacks and drinks. Door prizes and participation prizes were awarded.
Fourth-grader, Gracie Moore was the top fundraiser.

Thanks to all the parents, teachers and students for their hard work and dedication in keeping this event a part of our Schoolfield tradition.

Do you remember the United Way drawing we had for a 4-course meal prepared by our very own, Chef Phillip Gardner? Well, Chef came through in a big way for the lucky winner. Nom, nom, nom!

3rd Course - Intermezzo

5th Course - Red Velvet Creme Brulee

post_text:
On Saturday, February 8th, the George Washington High School Indoor Ensembles traveled to Apex Friendship High School in Apex North Carolina.

The George Washington High School Indoor Percussion Ensemble braved a very long day and performed wonderfully!!!! GWHS Indoor Percussion won 1st place in Concert Scholastic A Competition.

The George Washington High School Winterguard performed later and was also very successful! The Winterguard competed in the largest classification of the day and placed third in Scholastic A3 Competition. As a result of their success, they have been reclassified (moved up) into Scholastic A2 classification!!

We are so proud of you!

post_text:
Today at Westwood Middle School, Ms. Fuller and Ms. Godfrey’s math 8 classes participated in a VDOE hula hoop activity to collect data to represent in scatter plots. Students held hands in a circle and had to count the number of students who could pass through the hula hoop at various times. They used the data to create a scatter plot, make observations, and estimate a line of best fit. Students were actively engaged and
did a phenomenal job working collaboratively!

post_text: On Monday, February 3, 2020, the Junior dental assistants from George Washington High School visited the First Grade classrooms at Schoolfield Elementary in celebration of Dental Health Month. Students in the dental assistant program at G.W. sang songs about how to keep their teeth clean, showed students the proper way to brush and floss their teeth, and discussed the importance of good dental hygiene. Each student was also given a bag to go home with them containing a toothbrush, toothpaste, floss, and a coloring book. Thank you to Ms. Patricia Gobble, the dental instructor at G.W., as well as her dental assistants, for making this a memorable event!
text: On Monday, February 3, 2020, the Junior dental assistants from George Washington High School visited the First Grade classrooms at Schoolfield Elementary in celebration of Dental Health Month. Students in the dental assistant program at G.W. sang songs about how to keep their teeth clean, showed students the proper way to brush and floss their teeth, and discussed the importance of good dental hygiene. Each student was also given a bag to go home with them containing a toothbrush, toothpaste, floss, and a coloring book. Thank you to Ms. Patricia Gobble, the dental instructor at G.W., as well as her dental assistants, for making this a memorable event!

post_text: Career Planning, Profile of a Graduate, and software platforms are just a few of the topics covered during the Region VI counselor training in Roanoke, Virginia. Eighteen School Counselors and administrators from Danville Public Schools attended the training session conducted by Teresa “Gibby” Gibbons of Roanoke County Public School’s Burton Center for Arts and Technology. The Dan River Region Collaborative provided funding for counselors from Danville Public Schools and Pittsylvania County Schools to attend. Training for Region VI School Counselors will continue throughout the academic year as we prepare students for college and careers.

post_text:
Meet ACEC's Two Newest GED Graduates!

It is with much excitement that ACEC announces our two newest GED Graduates from last night's Pearson Vue Test Session.

Juan Ramirez is from Martinsville and works in Greensboro, NC at Harris Teeter. He chose our center to work on his GED Certificate because of our solid online reviews. Juan is interested in continuing his post-secondary studies at a community college close to home. He has an appointment with the Trio Program to help make this happen.

Zair Custis also received his GED Diploma last night. He is very interested in obtaining his commercial driver's license. Sharon Harris from DCC will meet with him to discuss his options.

If you would like to be one of our success stories, call Mary Dumont at 434.799.6471 or stop by our center located at 141 Goode Street.

post_text:
Local attorney Micheal Nicholas conducted a Mock Trial and spoke about the powers and structures of the Virginia Court System in Mr. Kirk and Mr. O’Sick’s Civics classes at Bonner Middle School.

Students played the role of judge, prosecuting attorney, defense attorney, and witnesses to learn about the criminal court process.

At the end of the session, the classes voted for acquittal or convictions on each of the charges presented in the classroom courtroom.

post_text: Our very own Phillip Gardner, Director of Child Nutrition Services, was hand-selected to be apart of the Census 2020 public service announcement. Phillip and his Child Nutrition staff members were on their radar because of videos and national attention surrounding the DPS Food Truck! The results of the 2020 Census will inform decisions about allocating hundreds of billions of dollars in federal funding to communities across the country—for hospitals, fire departments, school lunch programs, and other critical programs and services. Funding is critical so that we can continue and expand upon innovative programs like the Food Truck.

Mark Aron shared a post to the group: Southside News & Views.
January 13 at 5:39 PM ·

Wonderful news from the City of Danville Police Department today!

WWW.RIVERCITYTV.ORG
City of Danville, Virginia Police Department Reaches Milestone in Training

River City TV
January 13 at 2:46 PM ·

The City of Danville Police Department will reach a major training milestone this week, as 100 percent of the sworn officers within the department will have received Crisis Intervention Training. We spoke with a trainer today at Danville Pittsylvania Community Services who has partnered with the department as well as other public safety entities in the community to form a Crisis Intervention Team through this training to assist officers and others on how to handle these crisis situations.

post_text: We have 56 DPS teachers and assistant principals participating in the VDOE Teachers in Action Program (TAP). We have English Language Arts Teachers representing all grade grade levels from all schools. They will attend three workshops on Saturdays in Richmond, VA and will work cooperatively with teachers and assistant principals from Richmond, Petersburg, Greensville County, and Prince Edward County Schools. The sessions will he led by the English Language Arts staff at VDOE!

post_text: Mrs. Gleber's 4th-grade science class at Schoolfield made Christmas ornaments using the scientific method. The student's applied their knowledge of the scientific method by making predictions, forming a hypothesis, observing, and conducting an experiment. They applied heat to crayon shavings, followed the scientific process steps and wrote a conclusion synopsis. Attached are pictures of the student-created ornaments. Merry Christmas!

post_text:
Schoolfield students continue the yearly tradition of bringing in canned and non-perishable foods to be distributed throughout our community. All together they brought in almost 2000 items! Ms. Woods’ fifth grade class was the winner of a pizza party for bringing in 241 items. Ms. McCrae’s fourth graders brought in 240 items. And Ms. Harbodin’s multi-age classroom brought in 215 items! We are so proud of our students and their willingness to be of service to their community.

Pictured is Ms. Harbodin's class who brought in the most canned goods per student! Great Job to All!

post_text:
Students in the Health Professions Enrichment Program used pig feet, needle, thread, and loads of laughter to delicately stitch pig feet! During the final session at Sovah Health - Danville for the Health Profession Enrichment Program, students completed a training session on sutures and enjoyed their first surgical suture on pig feet!

Students will continue in the program with a visit to the Virginia Tech Carilion School of Medicine in the spring and 15 select students will have the opportunity to participate in a 4-day summer residential program at Virginia Tech in Blacksburg during the summer.

post_text:
Local Business Donates Products for Blog Writers!

Local print master Scott Chaney and his company Piedmont Printing & Graphics donated business cards to Galileo high school students. The students are writing blogs for their English class taught by Cary Wright. A Middle Border Forward guest speaker, Byron Gunn, brought up the idea of business cards so students can make better connections when they meet a possible blog partner, advertiser or contributor. Scott Chaney and Dagmar Morris created the cards with contact information and custom hashtags for each student blog. #partnershipsmatter

Are you an educator?!? Do you want to learn more about technology that you can integrate into your classroom, school, or district? Then Techpalooza is just for you!!!

Registration is now OPEN and slots are limited!!!

On Saturday, February 1, 2020, Danville Public Schools will host the Techpalooza Technology Conference at Bonner Middle School in Danville, Virginia from 7:45 am until 4:00 pm. We are looking for teachers, ITRTs, administrators, instructional support, etc that would like to attend. This technology conference is FREE for all districts and will include a Vendor Area. The conference does not include a complimentary lunch, but a food truck will be on site.

Click here to register ->http://bit.ly/TechpaloozaRegistration2020

Click here for additional information -> https://sites.google.com/mail.dps.k12.va.us/corisowers/home/techpalooza-2020

post_text: The National Weather Service has issued a winter weather advisory for the Danville area. They are predicting the Danville area will receive significant rainfall starting around 3:00 a.m. Friday morning. This rainfall mixed with the temperatures dropping below freezing can cause hazardous driving conditions. The temperature is not expected to rise above freezing until mid-morning. Decision like this are difficult, especially with a storm as unpredictable as this one, but the safety of our students and staff will always be our number one priority! Therefore, Danville Public Schools will be closed tomorrow, Friday, December 13, 2019. Central office staff and maintenance staff to report at noon, unless you want to use a half day of personal leave and be off the entire day which has been approved by the Superintendent. Be safe!
text: The National Weather Service has issued a winter weather advisory for the Danville area. They are predicting the Danville area will receive significant rainfall starting around 3:00 a.m. Friday morning. This rainfall mixed with the temperatures dropping below freezing can cause hazardous driving conditions. The temperature is not expected to rise above freezing until mid-morning. Decision like this are difficult, especially with a storm as unpredictable as this one, but the safety of our students and staff will always be our number one priority! Therefore, Danville Public Schools will be closed tomorrow, Friday, December 13, 2019. Central office staff and maintenance staff to report at noon, unless you want to use a half day of personal leave and be off the entire day which has been approved by the Superintendent. Be safe!

post_text:
Amazon Web Services Inc. (AWS), Sumitomo Electric Lightwave, and Danville Community College collaborated to offer a two-day Fusion Splicing Certificate Course on the fundamentals of fusion splicing fiber optic cable. Fusion splicing is the joining of two optical fibers to create a continuous light path, carrying data to technologies such as phones, the Internet, and TV. Marcos Huerta, Robert Walton, students in GW's Automotive Technology program, and Scott Brann, CTE Instructor, attended the course, received a certificate of training, and participated in graduation ceremony and reception.

L to R: Marcos Huerta, Scott Brann, Robert Walton, and Joyce Culley, Director of CTE.
text:

Marcos Huerta, Robert Walton, students in GW's Automotive Technology program, and Scott Brann, CTE Instructor, attended the course, received a certificate of training, and participated in graduation ceremony and reception.

Please join us for a full day of 50+ engaging technology sessions taught by ITRT's, teachers, administrators, and representatives from Achieve3000, EdTech Team, EdPuzzle, ITTIP, Learning A-Z, The Institute for Advanced Learning and Research, WHRO, and more!

Register to attend at bit.ly/TechpaloozaRegistration2020

Sign in and breakfast will be from 7:45 am - 8:25 am and sessions will start promptly at 8:30 am. Join us for this 100% FREE technology conference that is open for all districts to attend. Register now before sessions are full!

View detailed information about each session on our website: https://sites.google.com/mail.dps.k12.va.us/corisowers/home/techpalooza-2020

post_text:
Danville Public Schools Sees 32% Increase in CTE Program Credentials!

Danville Public Schools (DPS) celebrates a remarkable increase in the number of credentials earned by students through a myriad of CTE (Career and Technical Education) programs. During the 2017-2018 school year, students earned 689 credentials, and during the 2018-2019 school year, students earned 910 credentials. These numbers represent a 32% increase over the course of only one school year.

post_text:
GWHS Library's Lunch with a Professional!

On Thursday, November 21, the GWHS Library hosted a Lunch with a Professional. This inaugural event featured local professionals from the area who met with students and fielded questions about their jobs, training, and working in Danville. Participating professionals who volunteered their time for this event include Mayor Alonzo Jones; Vice Mayor Lee Vogler; Attorney Steven Gould; Chief Irvin with the Danville Fire Department; Architect Amanda Schlicting with Dewberry; and Dr. Tammy Hurt and Jacob Taylor with the Institute for Advanced Learning and Research.

GWHS Library's Lunch with a Professional!

This inaugural event featured local professionals from the area who met with students and fielded questions about their jobs, training, and working in Danville. Participating professionals who volunteered their time for this event include Mayor Alonzo Jones; Vice Mayor Lee Vogler; Attorney Steven Gould; Chief Irvin with the Danville Fire Department; Architect Amanda Schlicting with Dewberry; and Dr. Tammy Hurt and Jacob Taylor with the Institute for Advanced Learning and Research.

post_text:
The students in Hope Abernathy's 8th grade ELA (English Language Arts) class at Westwood have been working on genres. They completed stations on various genre activities:

Station 1: Students had to read and take notes on the definition of genre and categories
Station 2: Students had to match genres with their descriptions to spell a phrase
Station 3: Students had to complete a puzzle to determine the subcategories of each genre
Station 4: Students had to match books with genre descriptions.

This was a great way for students to get ready for their quiz on Thursday! #everychildeverydayeveryclassroom

post_text:
4th Graders at Gibson visit Jamestown!

4th graders at E.A. Gibson visited Jamestown on November 1st. The students went on three tours while there (James Fort Tour, First Africans Tour, Guided Archaearium Tour) and participated in two interactive exhibits (Ed Shed and the Dig Box).

For many of the students it was their first time on a boat (ferry). The students learned about life in Jamestown and how those living there learned to survive in the new world.

Thank you to the following businesses and organizations who made this trip possible for so many deserving students: Davenport Energy, Shields Power Washing, Walmart Danville - Mount Cross Rd, and the Danville Public Schools Education Foundation. A special thanks to Michelle Deighton Carlsen, a 4th grade math/history teacher at Gibson, for organizing this trip!

#everychildeverydayeveryclassroom, #Walmart, #WalmartGiving

post_text:
Congratulations to Sylvia H. Day for receiving a Community 500 Impact Project Sponsorship from Middle Border Forward.

Ms. Day is a Title I Parent Liaison with Danville Public Schools. Her project entitled “Life Savers” will provide first aid/CPR awareness to some of the parents/caregivers at G.L.H. Johnson Elementary and Park Avenue Elementary. It is her hope that the knowledge gained will promote better safety and wellness for each family within their respective communities.

The Community 5oo Impact Project Sponsorship is an initiative that allows opportunities for you to create change in your community.

Middle Border Forward is a nonprofit organization with the mission to “cultivate inclusive leadership, inspire community engagement, and create equitable access to opportunities” in the city of Danville, Pittsylvania County, and Caswell County. MBF’s work is focused on six identified pillars of community development: arts & culture, business, education, environment, health & wellness, and infrastructure.

The Westwood CARE Club is collecting supplies to benefit sheltered and fostered animals in our area. Beginning Nov. 1st, they will be accepting: gently used towels and blankets, newspapers, new or gently used dog and cat toys, cat treats, cat food (wet or dry), and any monetary donations.

All donations will be given to Danville Area Humane Society and Happy Tails to make the animals more comfortable in thier stay with these organizations.

The Westwood CARE Club is a community service club that teaches students to contribute and have pride in their community. Please drop off donations to the main office at Westwood Middle School located at 500 Apollo Dr.

post_text:
GWHS FCCLA Keeping it warm COAT DRIVE!

Members of the George Washington High School community service club FCCLA (Family Career and Community Leaders of America) are seeking donations for new or gently used coats, twin blankets, and socks for their KEEPING IT WARM coat drive. The club is partnering with the City of Danville Police Department and Riverside Dry Cleaning located at 1376 Piney Forest Road.

A donation drop is located at George Washington High School in front of the Security Station. Also, Riverside Dry Cleaning is accepting donations.

Date of Delivery is November 16, 2019, from 8:30 a.m. to 12:30 p.m. at Riverside Dry Cleaning. Please contact Phyllis Kittrell directly if you have questions - pkittrell@mail.dps.k12.va.us.

Gibson Library's Two Sentence Scary Story Contest!

Ms. Tracey Smith, the Library Media Specialist at Gibson, had a contest for the 4th and 5th grade classes where they had to write a Two Sentence Scary Story. There were tons of entries! The winners won a $5 gift certificate to the Book Fair that is coming up in 2 weeks and a free Frosty.

Here are the winners of the 2 Sentence Scary Story contest:
From Ms. Schmidt’s class - Samantha Alvarez-Pacheco
From Mrs. Thornton’s class - Octavious Foremar
From Mrs. Tucker’s class - Tyasia James
From Mrs. Messano’s class - Carter Swift
From Mrs. Carlsen’s class - Tenauri Terry
From Mrs. Robertson’s class - Sincere Graves
From Mrs. Felton’s class - Taliyah Barksdale

Pictured are the winners and Ms. Smith.

post_text:
In September 2019, the DPS Education Foundation posted that it had received a personal donation of $5,000 from Tiffany Harrison, a 1993 GWHS alum now living in Seattle. Mrs. Harrison, a CFO for The Boeing Company, made the generous donation to the Transition Stop, a one-stop "shop" for students who are absent from school because they lack basic life essentials.

Well, the story gets even better. In honor of Tiffany Harrison and Boeing employees, Boeing matched Mrs. Harrison's donation for a total contribution of $10,000 for the Transition Stop.

Stay tuned for an upcoming news release about the Transition Stop.
#partnershipsmatter #MadeInDPS

post_text:
Check out our Galileo TOPSoccer buddies!

US Youth Soccer TOPSoccer is a community-based training program for all athletes with intellectual, emotional, and or physical disabilities. The program strives to provide soccer opportunities for players to develop at their own pace in a safe, fun, and supportive / inclusive environment.

Anyone can be a BUDDY to assist students with special needs as they have the opportunity to play soccer. It is such a rewarding experience! Our students volunteer both in the fall and spring seasons giving up their Saturday mornings to be a BUDDY!
